TT

Gareth Davies of Numis

TT

A tougher than expected Q3

Pearson has this morning released a disappointing interim management statement

for the nine months to 30 September 2015. Underlying revenues declined in Q3 by

-4%, we had hoped for broadly flat. All divisions were negative on an underlying

basis in the quarter, with North America particularly disappointing to our estimates.

On the back of this disappointing quarter and new management guidance we cut

our 2015E and 2016E adjusted EPS estimates by c.6%. We reiterate our Reduce

recommendation and set a revised blended multiples based target of 1,040p

(previous 1,110p).

11:12 am
TT

● Q3 underlying down a disappointing -4%. For Q3 sales were down 2% in headline

terms and 4% in underlying terms. We had hoped for roughly flat underlying, from +1%

in H1 and -1% in Q1.

● Divisions all weak. In terms of the underlying performance in individual markets all

three divisions are negative. North America was down -1% underlying (H1 +3%), Core

was -5% (H1-5%) and Growth came in at -1% (H1 flat). So all three divisions weak,

with North America the material disappointment to H1.

● Guidance range cut, guiding to bottom of new range. Given currency, portfolio

changes and the weak trading environment management are cutting the EPS range

for the year from 75p to 80p to 70p to 75p and guiding to the bottom end of this range.

● A 6% cut to our estimates, retain Reduce recommendation. On the basis of the

9 month performance we cut our 2015E adjusted EPS from 74.5p to 69.9p. We see

a similar magnitude of reduction to our 2016E estimate from 74.7p to 70p. Clearly a

disappointing quarter, we remain very comfortable with our Reduce recommendation

on Pearson. We reduce our blended multiples based target from 1,110p to 1,040p.

TT

and Steve Liechti of Investec

TT

Poor update today (a day early) with all verticals below forecast. Prior FY EPS guidance of 75-80p moves to 70-75p post business exits and FX, but PSON now expects ‘around the bottom end of this’, so this is a new painful negative as we thought things had bottomed. Key cyclical/policy factors are still hurting markets. Offsetting this, PSON suggests it is gaining share in many areas and managing costs tightly, but mid-term concerns will come to the fore on structural change and PSON positioning in new conditions.
• Forecasts under review. Our previous FY15/16E FD adj EPS were 74.7p/75.5p (FactSet consensus 75.0p/76.2p), so new guidance implies a c. 5-6% EPS downgrade, with danger that we need to change FY16E more given a lower base. PSON guidance assumes no more M&A, a 15% tax rate (we had 16.8%) and £70m interest charge (we had £68m).

11:13 am
TT

• 9M sales poor at -2% LFL continuing, vs our f/c of +1% (1H +1%) and FY15E +1.3%. Arithmetically, implied 3Q LFL is -8%, but with the caveat that 3Q (and 4Q) are very big seasonally, so can disproportionately affect this number.
• N.America. 9M LFL sales -1% (f/c +2.5%) vs 1H +3% and FY15E +2.4%. Higher education was hurt by lower Community College enrolments, higher returns and regulation, offsetting market share gains. In Professional, VUE continued to deliver good growth. School sales grew modestly, with growth in State Assessments and Clinical Assessment partly offset by a decline in courseware.
• Core. 9M LFL sales -5% (f/c -3.5%) vs 1H -5% and FY15E +2.5%. Growth in Italy was more than offset by the impact of UK policy changes (school accountability measures and associated revenue recognition) and W. Europe decline. Difficulties with roll-out of new qualifications management platform.
• Growth. 9M LFL sales -1% (f/c +2%) vs 1H flat and FY15E +2.5%. Growth in China and Venture markets, Brazil stable, but S.Africa still weak given a poor school textbook market. Declines in India, Brazil sistemas and Saudi Arabia.
• Valuation - CY16E adj EV/EBITDA 10.6x, P/E 15.7x, FCF/div yield 5.7%/4.8%.

11:14 am
PM

Pearson (Short): Dinosaur tech/media deserves dinosaur valuation

PM

omg smile

PM

Well, at last, Pearson cut guidance. And it likely isn’t enough. And it’s very low quality and shrouded in one-offs and questionable statements of market share gains. Piece by piece Pearson’s legacy footprint is being taken apart and compounded by difficulties in adopting digital solutions.

The most important business, US core -5% in 3Q. Company cut FY guidance to 70-75p from 75-80p to account for disposals and F/X. Street at 75p but then Pearson guide to low end of new range. Not only that but it is based off a lower tax rate (guide to 15% from 17%). Biggest culprit, as we expected, was lower HE enrollments which the company had previously insisted wouldn't be an issue at the time of the H1 numbers. Q4 becomes almost impossible to hit targets in our view. This is likely just the first warning, with more to follow. Stock has seen upgrades of late in the hopes of a recovery in the ‘back to school’ season. Which given the pessimistic forecasts from the very education providers themselves (Devry, Apollo, Capella, APE) was odd in of itself.

11:15 am
PM

Ironically, the best performing asset in Pearson is the FT. Reaching a record paid circulation of 747,000, up 10% YoY. So what a great move to sell it, NOT.

Post the 10% fall we still see downside in Pearson. Having achieved the ‘dream’ of becoming a pure play education stock so the company should be valued against education peers. Which just serves to highlight how expensive the stock remains. Now trading on 11.5x F12M EV/EBITDA versus Grand Canyon on 6.7x, Apollo 1.6x, Capella 5.1x, Devry 5x, Graham 8.8x, K12 4x, American Public Ed 4.4x respective F12M EV/EBITDA multiples.

PM

So if you adjust for 2p for disposals, 3p for F/X movements and 2p for tax rate, then consider FY sales growth estimates of 4% growth are more likely are to come in at 0% for the next two years and there needs to be a rebasing of EPS, estimates, and valuation. Even if the 0.76 EPS was achievable for 2016 (questionable) what is a fair multiple? Well Pearson wants to be seen as a digital technology company. Perhaps a fairer comp is legacy technology given that technological deflationary forces make competitive offerings free in many instances. Well if legacy tech companies such as IBM and Hewlett Packard trade on 9x and 8x respective P/E multiples then perhaps Pearson should trade on a similar multiple . So place a 10x PE on the stock (with a chequered history of execution) and the stock is probably worth in the region of 750p even without change to 2016 estimates, some 45% lower than the current (not for long) consensus forecast price target of 1316p.

PM

Pearson remains exposed to a number of US policy headwinds. Pearson’s recovery is very much focused on top line acceleration yet the U.S. business, at ~60% of revenues, has multiple headwinds. We remain sellers.

11:18 am

there was quite a sell off of ARM towards the end of the summer

PM

here's Aviate

PM

Q3 Sales £243m ahead of £240m, EPS inline. The power of the long term business model is coming through. Need proof? End semi market is growing just 2% (Gartner, WSTS estimates etc) in 2015 so note ARM's sales are +23% YoY year-to-date. Key royalty growth is up an outstanding +37% YoY in US$ terms in Q3 versus market growth of -2%. Simply stunning. What’s more Q3 delivered accelerating growth: headline 24% sales growth in sterling terms and 17% in USD, thanks to the two key metrics of processor licensing +9% in Q3 (+6% YTD) and royalty processors +48% in Q3 (+45% YTD). High end, high royalty v8a penetration is an incredible 60% of smartphone design wins. Could be as high as 75% at the exit run rate of Q4 (had previously expected 60% at end of year).

11:18 am
PM

Now you must remember that ARM reports revenues one quarter after licensees shipments in Q2. So it is worth remembering that Q2 was when smartphone chip volumes and end markets reportedly fell off a cliff (over a dozen related semiconductor company warnings). So these great set of results mean just one thing. ARM is gaining further market share, higher ARM content, and higher royalty rate and newer technology take rates.

36 processor licenses signed which is a driver of future royalty growth. Solid. 50% of new Mali licenses are for (higher royalty rate) next gen processors, six ARMv8 high margin processor licenses sold. It is the very essence of the leading edge solutions that is now clearly driving growth. Increasing royalty revenue due to increasing shipments of chips containing ARM's latest technology, ARMv8-A, big.LITTLE and Mali graphics. Overall 3.6 billion chips shipped in Q3, up 20% YoY. Next generation royalty rates have the potential to be 5x the rate they were in 2011.

PM

While operating expenses are likely to move higher in the short term this was well flagged at last month’s analyst day. ARM is beginning to see new adoption in servers and the datacentre. As we suggested last week on Intel’s results we suspected ARM was just beginning to sow the seeds of disruption in Intel’s DCG (Data Centre Group) which is 60% of Intel’s profits. ARM had less than 1% market share in servers in 2014 but have a path to a potential 25% share by the end of the decade.

We view this set of results as indicative of ARM’s unique offering in providing an ecosystem across all verticals, all geographies, all end markets. ARM now signs more embedded device licenses (think Vehicles, smart cards, embedded computing etc.) than smartphones. The fact is whether Samsung lose share to Huawei and Xiaomi, for example, or GM to BMW, ARM is literally at the core of all and the enabler of the move to the IoE (Internet of Everything).

PM

ARM is the most disruptive company on the planet. One that is a fraction of the market cap of the companies it is disrupting (hello Intel).

ARM remains a unequivocal BUY

However, as I have previously stated, trading at Argos during this year's important Christmas season seems less predictable than usual, as both retailers and customers determine whether to repeat last year's unusual Black Friday patterns. The combination of this trading uncertainty, an increased level of investment in the launch of Fast Track and the underlying profit reduction from Argos' challenging first half, mean that at this stage of the financial year we expect the Group's full-year benchmark profit before tax to be slightly below the bottom end of the current range of market expectations of £115m to £140m."

11:26 am
PM

Why is Home Retail Group (HRG LN, 150p, Sell, FV 115p) warning before it has started the key selling season? Despite being Sellers this has somewhat exceeded even our bearish anticipation. Clearly 1H figures speak to a degree to extra cost loading in Argos, but we would expect that management has some better visibility on likely pricing/promotional levels at Argos and does not like what it sees. We feel that the window for improving base Argos profitability before the impacts of greater austerity on its customer base (clearly offsetting influences from the National Living Wage and reduced tax credits need to be assessed, but generally a risk factor re demand) and extra costs (NLW again) on its already very low EBIT margin level has now closed. While development and testing of the new Argos digital propositions is now complete, their roll-out is in our view likely to be margin dilutive, principally because the main digital conversion programme is not resulting in sales increases while opex will rise in these stores. Retail concepts can take a very long time to fade away or they can go suddenly. We hope that Argos demonstrates some durability but if demand is to be weak for its demographic we believe that its management should be at least contemplating the need to be more defensive, rather than progressing as if the market will give them time to implement their plans. We remain Sellers for the short and long term.

PM

We remain Sellers for the short and long term.

PM

Always refreshing to read some blunt sell side

11:26 am
PM

Another bloc...

PM

We note that HRG is quantifying the effect of the National Living Wage in 2016/17 at £15m gross of which one third was built into their expectation; i.e. £10m downgrade on NLW in 2016/17 (will try to mitigate). Additionally the inventory level at the half year 2015/16 is above their expectation at +6% vs. 1H sales -2%: they comment on Argos having more stock than wanted because of 1H sales under-performance. There has been a big operating cashflow deterioration LY 1H +£147m, CY -£6m mostly driven by working capital.

How should we value this? Is it the next Comet/MFI/Woolworths/Phones4U? Or will the digitisation give it sufficient flexibility and pricing power (from a low profit base starting point) to mitigate the issues likely to be faced by its traditional customer base? We believe at the very least that HRG/Argos has to demonstrate a more pro-active strategy in terms of defending itself, rather than just ploughing ahead with the modernisation plan without sufficient acknowledgement of the downside. The difference now vs. the last downturn is that Argos started that one with an EBIT margin of 8.5% vs. 2.5-3% now. It has de-geared the property base but lease adjusted debt still lies around 4x, so reducing the Group’s flexibility to reinforce valuation by liquidating its cash and near-cash (debtor book) resources.

We are at a loss to make a valuation call. In the short term there will be trading opportunities. But the unwinding of the Argos story leaves us needing to be persuaded that it is not staring into an abyss.

We see today's announcement to shrink the investment bank, attack the cost base in earnest and simplify group structure will – over time – drive value creation. But a weak Q3 in FICC and heavier costs will clearly drag before CS puts flesh on the skeletal new plan announced later on today. CS made just a ~3% ROE (we estimate backing out CDS litigation) for Q3, underscoring the fundamental need for change. Whilst many questions are still to be answered, at our first estimate of post money valuation of pro forma c. 8.8x 17e (including cost cuts) , we see supportive valuation to offset execution risk and Q3 weakness.

TT

Energy Investments After The Fall: Opportunity Or Slippery Slope?"
So begins the latest presentation from renowned short-seller Jim Chanos. What follows is a powerful outlining of the spirally debt dynamics now dominating the future of the oil industry. At the heart of Chanos's thesis is the contention that years of low interest rates, cheap financing, over-eager investors and ambitious managers have helped propel the boom in U.S. shale and imbue it with near unstoppable momentum; U.S. oil production is expected to grow 6 percent in 2015 despite a stunning 59 percent drop in the U.S. rig count over the past year.

PM

Ah, Izzy bumped into Chanos at Frieze last week. Said he was on good form

TT

The question hovering over the energy sector now is whether the continuous flow of capital investment that has propped up shale firms for so long continues. There are signs that it might not. Spreads on the bonds issued by energy companies are currently 480 basis points wider than average yield on the debt of junk-rated companies, meaning investors are (finally) demanding extra return to compensate them for the added risk of E&P.

PM

Stagnating rig productivity shows U.S. shale oil producers are running out of tricks to pump more with less in the face of crashing prices and points to a slide in output that should help rebalance global markets.

Over the 16 months of the crude price rout, production from new wells drilled by each rig has risen about 30 percent as companies refined their techniques, idled slower rigs and shifted crews and high-speed rigs to "sweet spots" with the most oil.

Such "high-grading" helped shale oil firms push U.S. output to the loftiest levels in decades even as oil tumbled by half to less than $50 a barrel and firms slashed rig fleets by 60 percent.

Let barclays explain

PM

1Q16 results were ahead of expectations, both in terms of KPIs (churn better in most
countries, UK broadband strong) and financials (1% beat at revenues and 6% at
EBITA vs. Barclays and 2% vs. ZoneFinance consensus). In what was supposed to be
fiscal 2016’s toughest quarter with BT and Mediaset advertising their Champions
League exclusive rights, Sky delivered UK TV net adds in line with last year and above
2012, 2013 and 2014 and the highest broadband net adds since 2012. In Italy, the
fall in subscribers is broadly similar to the last year and last quarter. Germany was
solid. In other words, no Champions League, no problem. We leave our forecasts
more or less unchanged. Yes, the market is more competitive in the UK with BT and
OTT players offering new alternatives, but Sky has now demonstrated they can still
grow nicely thanks to a superior TV product (7% revenue and 20% EBITA growth in
the UK in Q1). Sky should show solid results for the next 12 months at least (we
forecast 11% EPS growth in FY16E) and offers a 3% dividend yield. For such a Total
Shareholder Return the stock is not overly expensive at 18x 2016E P/E. Re-iterate
Overweight with unchanged 1,175p price target.

Wentworth golfers face missing the cut after the venerable club’s new Chinese management told them they must pay a £100,000 fee or lose their membership

TT

Under the new membership structure, which will take effect in 2017, existing members will have to pay £100,000 for a debenture share, in addition to a £16,000 annual subscription. Newcomers will have to pay £125,000 for the debenture or a non-equity membership, of which only about 800 will be sold by invitation.

Here's JPM

PM

The ECB is unlikely to make a policy change at Thursday’s policy meeting, but continues to face three big questions. First, is further easing needed in the near-term to counter growth spillovers from abroad and the tightening in financial market conditions over the past few months? Second, does enough monetary easing remain in the pipeline to meet the inflation objective over the medium-term, even if growth evolves as expected? Third, what tools should be used if the ECB decides to do more? In terms of our own call, we continue to see the ECB on hold but regard this as a very close call both in the near-term (December/January), due to growth risks, and for next spring, due to the medium-term inflation outlook. Should the ECB decide to act, we continue to see QE extensions as more likely than deposit rate cuts.

12:06 pm
PM

Assessing near-term risks
On Thursday, the ECB is likely to remain preoccupied with the first of these questions, trying to assess downside risks to the near-term outlook. Financial conditions have tightened in recent months, with the currency significantly firmer. But, even Draghi has continued to express satisfaction with the impact QE is having through domestic channels. In contrast, the ECB is likely to have become more concerned about the global backdrop. This is because there are now some signs of spillover through real channels, e.g. in exports and in German industrial orders from non-Euro area countries.

But, we do not expect these near-term risks to prompt the ECB to signal an imminent policy response on Thursday. This is partly because the data are not clearly undershooting the latest ECB staff projections, but also because more than half of the planned QE purchases have yet to be carried out. For an imminent response, the ECB likely needs to see clearer signs of economic weakness, such as a rapid 1-1.5pt decline in the composite PMI. In absence of this, we think Draghi will stick with last month’s message that the ECB is watching the data closely and that it is ready to act, if needed. He will point to the new ECB staff projections in December, which will allow him to reinforce a dovish tone.

PM

What is the medium-term target?
In the background of the near-term debate, there is a question over the medium-term. In September, the ECB staff revised down its core inflation forecast by 0.2%-pts to 1.6%oya for 2017 and the currency appreciation since then could knock another tenth off this. Surprisingly, this was not seen as a “fundamental” forecast change, with inflation still expected to “gradually” increase “over the coming years”. In our view, this raises doubt about what inflation rate the ECB is targeting and is something that will eventually be debated (e.g. in March/June), even if growth holds up and keeps the ECB on hold in the near-term. But, by that time, inflation projections for 2018 will be available and could complicate the debate. More clarity on the ECB's thinking on this would be welcome, in our view.

PM

All instruments?
Over the past month, there has been much interest in whether the ECB could cut its deposit rate further (from -0.20%). Last September, Draghi said that “technical adjustments”, i.e., further cuts, “are not going to be possible any longer”. Going back on this would be awkward, but likely manageable. And we doubt Draghi would want to rule out a further deposit rate cut. But, we suspect that the debate at this week’s meeting will focus on the outlook, rather than on instruments. And, hence, Draghi could somewhat dodge the issue by saying that instruments have yet to be fully discussed and directing most attention to the possibility of QE extensions (size, composition, duration).

But, while we think Draghi will keep the door to a further deposit rate cut open, we still regard an extension of QE as more likely than a deposit rate cut. Admittedly, a deposit rate cut would act quickly. But, the ECB has consistently directed attention to QE as the preferred instrument. In addition, the scope to cut the deposit rate further is relatively limited, its impact is arguably rising anyway as QE purchases increase the level of excess reserves, it could have possible “currency war” implications, and public opinion may oppose it more than QE extension (due to its more overt impact on savers).
